articles.headline: Boeing Faces a Steep Climb in Catching Up to Airbus
articles.snippet: As Boeing works to address quality control issues, its new chief starts at a disadvantage in competing with the other big maker of passenger planes.
articles.abstract: As Boeing works to address quality control issues, its new chief starts at a disadvantage in competing with the other big maker of passenger planes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Airbus scored a major victory: For the first time in its history, more of its passenger planes were flying around the world than those made by its rival, Boeing. Airbus has only tightened its grip on the market since.

articles.headline: When Will They Speak Again? Once Close, Biden and Pelosi Are at Odds.
articles.snippet: President Biden is upset that Representative Nancy Pelosi worked to get him out of the race. She is losing sleep over it.
articles.abstract: President Biden is upset that Representative Nancy Pelosi worked to get him out of the race. She is losing sleep over it.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited San Francisco as a freshly minted senator and single father in the early 1970s, it was a well-known local fund-raiser and stay-at-home mother of five, Nancy Pelosi, who lent him her Jeep to get around town.

articles.headline: In Gaza, Israel’s Military Has Reached the End of the Line, U.S. Officials Say
articles.snippet: Israel has severely set back Hamas but will never be able to completely eliminate the group, U.S. officials said.
articles.abstract: Israel has severely set back Hamas but will never be able to completely eliminate the group, U.S. officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel has achieved all that it can militarily in Gaza, according to senior American officials, who say continued bombings are only increasing risks to civilians while the possibility of further weakening Hamas has diminished.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: To Solve Its Housing Crisis, Britain Turns to an Old Idea: New Towns
articles.snippet: By reviving an idea from the 1940s, the Labour Party government is hoping to overcome the development hurdles that have plagued previous efforts with a plan to build new communities.
articles.abstract: By reviving an idea from the 1940s, the Labour Party government is hoping to overcome the development hurdles that have plagued previous efforts with a plan to build new communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a baking hot afternoon in July, Firouz Thompson proudly drove down the freshly paved road that leads into Northstowe, a new town about six miles northwest of Cambridge, England.

articles.headline: A Chinese Self-Driving Start-Up Is About to Go Public in the U.S.
articles.snippet: WeRide, a $5 billion software maker, is set for an I.P.O. amid geopolitical risks and a rush by Chinese automotive tech firms to raise money in the United States.
articles.abstract: WeRide, a $5 billion software maker, is set for an I.P.O. amid geopolitical risks and a rush by Chinese automotive tech firms to raise money in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of China’s leading autonomous driving start-ups is set to go public in New York as soon as this week, with the strained relationship between Beijing and Washington lurking in the background.

articles.headline: U.S. Unveils Price Limits for 10 Costly or Common Medications
articles.snippet: The Biden administration said it would have saved $6 billion had the new prices been in effect last year.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration said it would have saved $6 billion had the new prices been in effect last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Thursday unveiled the results of landmark drug price negotiations between Medicare and pharmaceutical companies, allowing President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris to cast themselves as confronting the drug industry on behalf of older Americans at a critical moment in the presidential campaign.
articles.byline: By Noah Weiland and Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: Tim Walz’s Bumpy Road to Gun Control
articles.snippet: The vice-presidential candidate wasn’t always tough on firearms. When he ran for Minnesota governor, he tried to recast a legislative record that had gotten high marks from the N.R.A.
articles.abstract: The vice-presidential candidate wasn’t always tough on firearms. When he ran for Minnesota governor, he tried to recast a legislative record that had gotten high marks from the N.R.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a tight primary for governor in 2018, Tim Walz, then a congressman from a conservative pro-gun district in Minnesota, was rebuked for his A ratings from the National Rifle Association. After a school shooting in Parkland, Fla., he went on the offensive.

articles.headline: Walmart Sees Higher Sales From Picky Shoppers
articles.snippet: The retail giant raised its forecasts as it attracted bargain-hunting shoppers strained by inflation, drawing in high-income households in particular.
articles.abstract: The retail giant raised its forecasts as it attracted bargain-hunting shoppers strained by inflation, drawing in high-income households in particular.
articles.lead_paragraph: The state of the economy can be confusing. Consumers, stung by high inflation for two years and navigating a slowing job market, are still spending at a decent clip — but on store-brand soda, not new refrigerators. That puts Walmart, the company that made low prices a mantra, in a good position.

articles.headline: He Still Thought He Could Win: Inside Biden’s Decision to Drop Out
articles.snippet: People close to President Biden say he believes he could have won a second term. But he came to realize that the fight would rip apart the Democratic Party that he had served his whole life.
articles.abstract: People close to President Biden say he believes he could have won a second term. But he came to realize that the fight would rip apart the Democratic Party that he had served his whole life.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the end, he was alone.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Katie Rogers and Adam Entous
